entry.title: Introduction to statsmodels
entry.summary: A quick introduction to statsmodels and why you should consider using it
entry.content:
<style type="text/css">/*!
*
* IPython notebook
*
*/
/* CSS font colors for translated ANSI escape sequences */
/* The color values are a mix of
   http://www.xcolors.net/dl/baskerville-ivorylight and
   http://www.xcolors.net/dl/euphrasia */
.ansi-black-fg {
  color: #3E424D;
}
.ansi-black-bg {
  background-color: #3E424D;
}
.ansi-black-intense-fg {
  color: #282C36;
}
.ansi-black-intense-bg {
  background-color: #282C36;
}
.ansi-red-fg {
  color: #E75C58;
}
.ansi-red-bg {
  background-color: #E75C58;
}
.ansi-red-intense-fg {
  color: #B22B31;
}
.ansi-red-intense-bg {
  background-color: #B22B31;
}
.ansi-green-fg {
  color: #00A250;
}
.ansi-green-bg {
  background-color: #00A250;
}
.ansi-green-intense-fg {
  color: #007427;
}
.ansi-green-intense-bg {
  background-color: #007427;
}
.ansi-yellow-fg {
  color: #DDB62B;
}
.ansi-yellow-bg {
  background-color: #DDB62B;
}
.ansi-yellow-intense-fg {
  color: #B27D12;
}
.ansi-yellow-intense-bg {
  background-color: #B27D12;
}
.ansi-blue-fg {
  color: #208FFB;
}
.ansi-blue-bg {
  background-color: #208FFB;
}
.ansi-blue-intense-fg {
  color: #0065CA;
}
.ansi-blue-intense-bg {
  background-color: #0065CA;
}
.ansi-magenta-fg {
  color: #D160C4;
}
.ansi-magenta-bg {
  background-color: #D160C4;
}
.ansi-magenta-intense-fg {
  color: #A03196;
}
.ansi-magenta-intense-bg {
  background-color: #A03196;
}
.ansi-cyan-fg {
  color: #60C6C8;
}
.ansi-cyan-bg {
  background-color: #60C6C8;
}
.ansi-cyan-intense-fg {
  color: #258F8F;
}
.ansi-cyan-intense-bg {
  background-color: #258F8F;
}
.ansi-white-fg {
  color: #C5C1B4;
}
.ansi-white-bg {
  background-color: #C5C1B4;
}
.ansi-white-intense-fg {
  color: #A1A6B2;
}
.ansi-white-intense-bg {
  background-color: #A1A6B2;
}
.ansi-default-inverse-fg {
  color: #FFFFFF;
}
.ansi-default-inverse-bg {
  background-color: #000000;
}
.ansi-bold {
  font-weight: bold;
}
.ansi-underline {
  text-decoration: underline;
}
/* The following styles are deprecated an will be removed in a future version */
.ansibold {
  font-weight: bold;
}
.ansi-inverse {
  outline: 0.5px dotted;
}
/* use dark versions for foreground, to improve visibility */
.ansiblack {
  color: black;
}
.ansired {
  color: darkred;
}
.ansigreen {
  color: darkgreen;
}
.ansiyellow {
  color: #c4a000;
}
.ansiblue {
  color: darkblue;
}
.ansipurple {
  color: darkviolet;
}
.ansicyan {
  color: steelblue;
}
.ansigray {
  color: gray;
}
/* and light for background, for the same reason */
.ansibgblack {
  background-color: black;
}
.ansibgred {
  background-color: red;
}
.ansibggreen {
  background-color: green;
}
.ansibgyellow {
  background-color: yellow;
}
.ansibgblue {
  background-color: blue;
}
.ansibgpurple {
  background-color: magenta;
}
.ansibgcyan {
  background-color: cyan;
}
.ansibggray {
  background-color: gray;
}
div.cell {
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
  border-radius: 2px;
  box-sizing: border-box;
  -moz-box-sizing: border-box;
  -webkit-box-sizing: border-box;
  border-width: 1px;
  border-style: solid;
  border-color: transparent;
  width: 100%;
  padding: 5px;
  /* This acts as a spacer between cells, that is outside the border */
  margin: 0px;
  outline: none;
  position: relative;
  overflow: visible;
}
div.cell:before {
  position: absolute;
  display: block;
  top: -1px;
  left: -1px;
  width: 5px;
  height: calc(100% +  2px);
  content: '';
  background: transparent;
}
div.cell.jupyter-soft-selected {
  border-left-color: #E3F2FD;
  border-left-width: 1px;
  padding-left: 5px;
  border-right-color: #E3F2FD;
  border-right-width: 1px;
  background: #E3F2FD;
}
@media print {
  div.cell.jupyter-soft-selected {
    border-color: transparent;
  }
}
div.cell.selected,
div.cell.selected.jupyter-soft-selected {
  border-color: #ababab;
}
div.cell.selected:before,
div.cell.selected.jupyter-soft-selected:before {
  position: absolute;
  display: block;
  top: -1px;
  left: -1px;
  width: 5px;
  height: calc(100% +  2px);
  content: '';
  background: #42A5F5;
}
@media print {
  div.cell.selected,
  div.cell.selected.jupyter-soft-selected {
    border-color: transparent;
  }
}
.edit_mode div.cell.selected {
  border-color: #66BB6A;
}
.edit_mode div.cell.selected:before {
  position: absolute;
  display: block;
  top: -1px;
  left: -1px;
  width: 5px;
  height: calc(100% +  2px);
  content: '';
  background: #66BB6A;
}
@media print {
  .edit_mode div.cell.selected {
    border-color: transparent;
  }
}
.prompt {
  /* This needs to be wide enough for 3 digit prompt numbers: In[100]: */
  min-width: 14ex;
  /* This padding is tuned to match the padding on the CodeMirror editor. */
  padding: 0.4em;
  margin: 0px;
  font-family: monospace;
  text-align: right;
  /* This has to match that of the the CodeMirror class line-height below */
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  /* Don't highlight prompt number selection */
  -webkit-touch-callout: none;
  -webkit-user-select: none;
  -khtml-user-select: none;
  -moz-user-select: none;
  -ms-user-select: none;
  user-select: none;
  /* Use default cursor */
  cursor: default;
}
@media (max-width: 540px) {
  .prompt {
    text-align: left;
  }
}
div.inner_cell {
  min-width: 0;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
  /* Old browsers */
  -webkit-box-flex: 1;
  -moz-box-flex: 1;
  box-flex: 1;
  /* Modern browsers */
  flex: 1;
}
/* input_area and input_prompt must match in top border and margin for alignment */
div.input_area {
  border: 1px solid #cfcfcf;
  border-radius: 2px;
  background: #f7f7f7;
  line-height: 1.21429em;
}
/* This is needed so that empty prompt areas can collapse to zero height when there
   is no content in the output_subarea and the prompt. The main purpose of this is
   to make sure that empty JavaScript output_subareas have no height. */
div.prompt:empty {
  padding-top: 0;
  padding-bottom: 0;
}
div.unrecognized_cell {
  padding: 5px 5px 5px 0px;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: horizontal;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: horizontal;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: horizontal;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: row;
  align-items: stretch;
}
div.unrecognized_cell .inner_cell {
  border-radius: 2px;
  padding: 5px;
  font-weight: bold;
  color: red;
  border: 1px solid #cfcfcf;
  background: #eaeaea;
}
div.unrecognized_cell .inner_cell a {
  color: inherit;
  text-decoration: none;
}
div.unrecognized_cell .inner_cell a:hover {
  color: inherit;
  text-decoration: none;
}
@media (max-width: 540px) {
  div.unrecognized_cell > div.prompt {
    display: none;
  }
}
div.code_cell {
  /* avoid page breaking on code cells when printing */
}
@media print {
  div.code_cell {
    page-break-inside: avoid;
  }
}
/* any special styling for code cells that are currently running goes here */
div.input {
  page-break-inside: avoid;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: horizontal;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: horizontal;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: horizontal;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: row;
  align-items: stretch;
}
@media (max-width: 540px) {
  div.input {
    /* Old browsers */
    display: -webkit-box;
    -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
    -webkit-box-align: stretch;
    display: -moz-box;
    -moz-box-orient: vertical;
    -moz-box-align: stretch;
    display: box;
    box-orient: vertical;
    box-align: stretch;
    /* Modern browsers */
    display: flex;
    flex-direction: column;
    align-items: stretch;
  }
}
/* input_area and input_prompt must match in top border and margin for alignment */
div.input_prompt {
  color: #303F9F;
  border-top: 1px solid transparent;
}
div.input_area > div.highlight {
  margin: 0.4em;
  border: none;
  padding: 0px;
  background-color: transparent;
}
div.input_area > div.highlight > pre {
  margin: 0px;
  border: none;
  padding: 0px;
  background-color: transparent;
}
/* The following gets added to the <head> if it is detected that the user has a
 * monospace font with inconsistent normal/bold/italic height.  See
 * notebookmain.js.  Such fonts will have keywords vertically offset with
 * respect to the rest of the text.  The user should select a better font.
 * See: https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/1503
 *
 * .CodeMirror span {
 *      vertical-align: bottom;
 * }
 */
.CodeMirror {
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  /* Changed from 1em to our global default */
  font-size: 14px;
  height: auto;
  /* Changed to auto to autogrow */
  background: none;
  /* Changed from white to allow our bg to show through */
}
.CodeMirror-scroll {
  /*  The CodeMirror docs are a bit fuzzy on if overflow-y should be hidden or visible.*/
  /*  We have found that if it is visible, vertical scrollbars appear with font size changes.*/
  overflow-y: hidden;
  overflow-x: auto;
}
.CodeMirror-lines {
  /* In CM2, this used to be 0.4em, but in CM3 it went to 4px. We need the em value because */
  /* we have set a different line-height and want this to scale with that. */
  /* Note that this should set vertical padding only, since CodeMirror assumes
       that horizontal padding will be set on CodeMirror pre */
  padding: 0.4em 0;
}
.CodeMirror-linenumber {
  padding: 0 8px 0 4px;
}
.CodeMirror-gutters {
  border-bottom-left-radius: 2px;
  border-top-left-radius: 2px;
}
.CodeMirror pre {
  /* In CM3 this went to 4px from 0 in CM2. This sets horizontal padding only,
    use .CodeMirror-lines for vertical */
  padding: 0 0.4em;
  border: 0;
  border-radius: 0;
}
.CodeMirror-cursor {
  border-left: 1.4px solid black;
}
@media screen and (min-width: 2138px) and (max-width: 4319px) {
  .CodeMirror-cursor {
    border-left: 2px solid black;
  }
}
@media screen and (min-width: 4320px) {
  .CodeMirror-cursor {
    border-left: 4px solid black;
  }
}
/*

Original style from softwaremaniacs.org (c) Ivan Sagalaev <Maniac@SoftwareManiacs.Org>
Adapted from GitHub theme

*/
.highlight-base {
  color: #000;
}
.highlight-variable {
  color: #000;
}
.highlight-variable-2 {
  color: #1a1a1a;
}
.highlight-variable-3 {
  color: #333333;
}
.highlight-string {
  color: #BA2121;
}
.highlight-comment {
  color: #408080;
  font-style: italic;
}
.highlight-number {
  color: #080;
}
.highlight-atom {
  color: #88F;
}
.highlight-keyword {
  color: #008000;
  font-weight: bold;
}
.highlight-builtin {
  color: #008000;
}
.highlight-error {
  color: #f00;
}
.highlight-operator {
  color: #AA22FF;
  font-weight: bold;
}
.highlight-meta {
  color: #AA22FF;
}
/* previously not defined, copying from default codemirror */
.highlight-def {
  color: #00f;
}
.highlight-string-2 {
  color: #f50;
}
.highlight-qualifier {
  color: #555;
}
.highlight-bracket {
  color: #997;
}
.highlight-tag {
  color: #170;
}
.highlight-attribute {
  color: #00c;
}
.highlight-header {
  color: blue;
}
.highlight-quote {
  color: #090;
}
.highlight-link {
  color: #00c;
}
/* apply the same style to codemirror */
.cm-s-ipython span.cm-keyword {
  color: #008000;
  font-weight: bold;
}
.cm-s-ipython span.cm-atom {
  color: #88F;
}
.cm-s-ipython span.cm-number {
  color: #080;
}
.cm-s-ipython span.cm-def {
  color: #00f;
}
.cm-s-ipython span.cm-variable {
  color: #000;
}
.cm-s-ipython span.cm-operator {
  color: #AA22FF;
  font-weight: bold;
}
.cm-s-ipython span.cm-variable-2 {
  color: #1a1a1a;
}
.cm-s-ipython span.cm-variable-3 {
  color: #333333;
}
.cm-s-ipython span.cm-comment {
  color: #408080;
  font-style: italic;
}
.cm-s-ipython span.cm-string {
  color: #BA2121;
}
.cm-s-ipython span.cm-string-2 {
  color: #f50;
}
.cm-s-ipython span.cm-meta {
  color: #AA22FF;
}
.cm-s-ipython span.cm-qualifier {
  color: #555;
}
.cm-s-ipython span.cm-builtin {
  color: #008000;
}
.cm-s-ipython span.cm-bracket {
  color: #997;
}
.cm-s-ipython span.cm-tag {
  color: #170;
}
.cm-s-ipython span.cm-attribute {
  color: #00c;
}
.cm-s-ipython span.cm-header {
  color: blue;
}
.cm-s-ipython span.cm-quote {
  color: #090;
}
.cm-s-ipython span.cm-link {
  color: #00c;
}
.cm-s-ipython span.cm-error {
  color: #f00;
}
.cm-s-ipython span.cm-tab {
  background: url(data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAADAAAAAMCAYAAAAkuj5RAAAAAXNSR0IArs4c6QAAAGFJREFUSMft1LsRQFAQheHPowAKoACx3IgEKtaEHujDjORSgWTH/ZOdnZOcM/sgk/kFFWY0qV8foQwS4MKBCS3qR6ixBJvElOobYAtivseIE120FaowJPN75GMu8j/LfMwNjh4HUpwg4LUAAAAASUVORK5CYII=);
  background-position: right;
  background-repeat: no-repeat;
}
div.output_wrapper {
  /* this position must be relative to enable descendents to be absolute within it */
  position: relative;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
  z-index: 1;
}
/* class for the output area when it should be height-limited */
div.output_scroll {
  /* ideally, this would be max-height, but FF barfs all over that */
  height: 24em;
  /* FF needs this *and the wrapper* to specify full width, or it will shrinkwrap */
  width: 100%;
  overflow: auto;
  border-radius: 2px;
  -webkit-box-shadow: inset 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);
  box-shadow: inset 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);
  display: block;
}
/* output div while it is collapsed */
div.output_collapsed {
  margin: 0px;
  padding: 0px;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
}
div.out_prompt_overlay {
  height: 100%;
  padding: 0px 0.4em;
  position: absolute;
  border-radius: 2px;
}
div.out_prompt_overlay:hover {
  /* use inner shadow to get border that is computed the same on WebKit/FF */
  -webkit-box-shadow: inset 0 0 1px #000;
  box-shadow: inset 0 0 1px #000;
  background: rgba(240, 240, 240, 0.5);
}
div.output_prompt {
  color: #D84315;
}
/* This class is the outer container of all output sections. */
div.output_area {
  padding: 0px;
  page-break-inside: avoid;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: horizontal;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: horizontal;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: horizontal;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: row;
  align-items: stretch;
}
div.output_area .MathJax_Display {
  text-align: left !important;
}
div.output_area 
div.output_area 
div.output_area img,
div.output_area svg {
  max-width: 100%;
  height: auto;
}
div.output_area img.unconfined,
div.output_area svg.unconfined {
  max-width: none;
}
div.output_area .mglyph > img {
  max-width: none;
}
/* This is needed to protect the pre formating from global settings such
   as that of bootstrap */
.output {
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
}
@media (max-width: 540px) {
  div.output_area {
    /* Old browsers */
    display: -webkit-box;
    -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
    -webkit-box-align: stretch;
    display: -moz-box;
    -moz-box-orient: vertical;
    -moz-box-align: stretch;
    display: box;
    box-orient: vertical;
    box-align: stretch;
    /* Modern browsers */
    display: flex;
    flex-direction: column;
    align-items: stretch;
  }
}
div.output_area pre {
  margin: 0;
  padding: 1px 0 1px 0;
  border: 0;
  vertical-align: baseline;
  color: black;
  background-color: transparent;
  border-radius: 0;
}
/* This class is for the output subarea inside the output_area and after
   the prompt div. */
div.output_subarea {
  overflow-x: auto;
  padding: 0.4em;
  /* Old browsers */
  -webkit-box-flex: 1;
  -moz-box-flex: 1;
  box-flex: 1;
  /* Modern browsers */
  flex: 1;
  max-width: calc(100% - 14ex);
}
div.output_scroll div.output_subarea {
  overflow-x: visible;
}
/* The rest of the output_* classes are for special styling of the different
   output types */
/* all text output has this class: */
div.output_text {
  text-align: left;
  color: #000;
  /* This has to match that of the the CodeMirror class line-height below */
  line-height: 1.21429em;
}
/* stdout/stderr are 'text' as well as 'stream', but execute_result/error are *not* streams */
div.output_stderr {
  background: #fdd;
  /* very light red background for stderr */
}
div.output_latex {
  text-align: left;
}
/* Empty output_javascript divs should have no height */
div.output_javascript:empty {
  padding: 0;
}
.js-error {
  color: darkred;
}
/* raw_input styles */
div.raw_input_container {
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  padding-top: 5px;
}
pre.raw_input_prompt {
  /* nothing needed here. */
}
input.raw_input {
  font-family: monospace;
  font-size: inherit;
  color: inherit;
  width: auto;
  /* make sure input baseline aligns with prompt */
  vertical-align: baseline;
  /* padding + margin = 0.5em between prompt and cursor */
  padding: 0em 0.25em;
  margin: 0em 0.25em;
}
input.raw_input:focus {
  box-shadow: none;
}
p.p-space {
  margin-bottom: 10px;
}
div.output_unrecognized {
  padding: 5px;
  font-weight: bold;
  color: red;
}
div.output_unrecognized a {
  color: inherit;
  text-decoration: none;
}
div.output_unrecognized a:hover {
  color: inherit;
  text-decoration: none;
}
.rendered_html {
  color: #000;
  /* any extras will just be numbers: */
}



.rendered_html :link {
  text-decoration: underline;
}
.rendered_html :visited {
  text-decoration: underline;
}






.rendered_html h1:first-child {
  margin-top: 0.538em;
}
.rendered_html h2:first-child {
  margin-top: 0.636em;
}
.rendered_html h3:first-child {
  margin-top: 0.777em;
}
.rendered_html h4:first-child {
  margin-top: 1em;
}
.rendered_html h5:first-child {
  margin-top: 1em;
}
.rendered_html h6:first-child {
  margin-top: 1em;
}
.rendered_html ul:not(.list-inline),
.rendered_html ol:not(.list-inline) {
  padding-left: 2em;
}

 .highlight pre  .s2 { color: #BA2121 } /* Literal.String.Double */

 .highlight pre  .sh { color: #BA2121 } /* Literal.String.Heredoc */
 .highlight pre  .si { color: #A45A77; font-weight: bold } /* Literal.String.Interpol */

 .highlight pre  .sr { color: #A45A77 } /* Literal.String.Regex */

 .highlight pre  .ss { color: #19177C } /* Literal.String.Symbol */
 .highlight pre  .bp { color: #008000 } /* Name.Builtin.Pseudo */
 .highlight pre  .fm { color: #0000FF } /* Name.Function.Magic */
 .highlight pre  .vc { color: #19177C } /* Name.Variable.Class */
 .highlight pre  .vg { color: #19177C } /* Name.Variable.Global */
 .highlight pre  .vi { color: #19177C } /* Name.Variable.Instance */
 .highlight pre  .vm { color: #19177C } /* Name.Variable.Magic */
 .highlight pre  .il { color: #666666 } /* Literal.Number.Integer.Long */</style><div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>While not as commonly used as <code>scikit-learn</code>, <a href="https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/index.html">statsmodels</a> is a relatively new and very powerful statistical package for Python. For users of <strong>R</strong>, this package will feel very familiar as it can support formula and returns many of the values of <strong>R</strong>'s <em>base</em> and <em>stats</em> libraries.</p>
<p>In this series, we'll focus on loading in some daily minimum temperature data from 1-1-1981 to 12-31-1990 and then fitting a Linear Regression (and when I write this, I mean a standard OLS regression) model to this data. We'll discuss:</p>
<ol>
<li>(very briefly) The <a href="https://patsy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/overview.html">patsy</a> library; a very useful library when doing modeling that also mirrors some <strong>R</strong> functionality.  </li>
<li>We'll fit a simple linear regressor and show how this matches with sklearn but gives you more metrics</li>
<li>We'll go through using radial basis functions to fit the data. If you've never seen <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basis_function#:~:text=In%20mathematics%2C%20a%20basis%20function,linear%20combination%20of%20basis%20vectors.">basis functions</a> before, you'll love them! They allow you to inject non-linearity into your OLS models and are very powerful (more on that later).</li>
</ol>
<p>So to get started, let's load a few basic libraries and the data. <strong>NOTE:</strong> I'm writing this in a Docker container so the data load is a bit more complex than just loading the data locally.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [1]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Creating some data for the example.  In this case we'll simulate some periodic data.  </span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">numpy</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">np</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">pandas</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">pd</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">matplotlib.pyplot</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">plt</span>

<span class="c1"># Set the Random Seed!</span>
<span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">seed</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1234</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [2]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># We'll want to import the .csv file so let's import Path and name the directory.</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">pathlib</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">Path</span>
<span class="n">data_dir</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'/opt/intro-to-statsmodels/data'</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [3]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Now load the data!</span>
<span class="n">file_path</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">Path</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data_dir</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="n">Path</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'min_temps.csv'</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">temp_df</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">read_csv</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">file_path</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="c1"># We can inspect the data now...</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">temp_df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>       Date  Temp
0  1/1/1981  20.7
1  1/2/1981  17.9
2  1/3/1981  18.8
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now at this point, we'll want to make some manipulations to the data. For starters, we want to make sure that the <code>Date</code> field is a <code>datetime</code> type.  In addition, we can create some features that we may want to incorporate in the model. For instance, maybe we think there are trends by year. Or we think there is a steady linear trend in all of the data. Let's add those features now.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [4]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">temp_df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Date'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span>  <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">to_datetime</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">temp_df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Date'</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">temp_df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Year'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">year</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">x</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">temp_df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Date'</span><span class="p">]]</span>
<span class="n">temp_df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Time'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span>  <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">x</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">x</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">range</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">temp_df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">shape</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])]</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">temp_df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>        Date  Temp  Year  Time
0 1981-01-01  20.7  1981     0
1 1981-01-02  17.9  1981     1
2 1981-01-03  18.8  1981     2
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [5]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Let's split the data into training and test sets based on dates.  We'll keep 1990 as our test set.</span>
<span class="n">train_df</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">temp_df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">loc</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">temp_df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Date'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o"><=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">to_datetime</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'1989-12-31'</span><span class="p">)]</span>
<span class="n">test_df</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">temp_df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">loc</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">temp_df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Date'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">>=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">to_datetime</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'1990-01-01'</span><span class="p">)]</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Patsy">Patsy<a class="anchor-link" href="#Patsy">¶</a></h2><p>Now it's time to import <code>patsy</code>. The main functionality of <code>patsy</code> is to create matrices based on formulas. This mimics native behavior of <strong>R</strong> and can be very very helpful in Python, even when not planning on using statsmodels.</p>
<p>This includes more complicated formulas, e.g. <code>y ~ x1 + time*(log(x2)-log(x3))</code>. In addition to this, <code>patsy</code> can create dummy columns for categories AND handle redundancy so that columns don't become linearly dependent, and even factor-level interaction terms. This is all beyond the scope of this talk, but it's a wonderful library that I would highly recommend to anyone as part of their modeling pipeline.</p>
<p>In our case, we'll just use them in the future to make matrices to feed into our linear models:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [6]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Import patsy to make our modeling work easier</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">patsy</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">dmatrices</span>

<span class="c1"># Naming the formula for the linear regression; here we just think temperature depends on a trend term</span>
<span class="c1"># NOTE: The intercept term is implicit; if we wanted to change that, simply write:</span>
<span class="c1">#           "Temp ~ 0 + Time"</span>
<span class="n">formula1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">"Temp ~ Time"</span>
<span class="c1"># Use Patsy to make the required matrices/arrays</span>
<span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">X_train</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">dmatrices</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">formula1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">data</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">train_df</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">X_test</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">dmatrices</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">formula1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">data</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">test_df</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>To see what's actually happening under the hood, let's call the function one more time and just look at the output.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [7]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">dmatrices</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">formula1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">data</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">train_df</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[7]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>(DesignMatrix with shape (3285, 1)

           1    10
           1    11
           1    12
           1    13
           1    14
           1    15
           1    16
           1    17
           1    18
           1    19
           1    20
           1    21
           1    22
           1    23
           1    24
           1    25
           1    26
           1    27
           1    28
           1    29
   [3255 rows omitted]
   Terms:
     'Intercept' (column 0)
     'Time' (column 1)
   (to view full data, use np.asarray(this_obj)))</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This may not seem like much at the moment, but in a bit, we'll revisit Patsy and how much time it can save us.</p>
<p>For now, let's pause and actually look at the data. These are the daily minimum temperatures in Melbourne, Australia from 1-1-1981 through 12-31-1990. We've kept 1990 as our hold-out, so in the plot below, we'll see the temperatures in blue from 1981 - 1989 and in red for 1990.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [9]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Let's visualize the data</span>
<span class="n">fig</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">ax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">subplots</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">figsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">20</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">6</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">train_df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Date'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">test_df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Date'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">color</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'r'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_title</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Daily Min Temps in Melbourne'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">fontsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">20</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">yaxis</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_label_text</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Temp'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">xaxis</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_label_text</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Date'</span><span class="p">);</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now let's start fitting some models! The first model we'll fit is actually using the linear regressor from <code>scikit-learn</code>. Our motivation to do this is to highlight stability of results across the systems and also to highlight some of the drawbacks of using <code>sklearn</code>. But to start, let's load the model, fit it and check out some coefficients:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [10]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># We'll load in sklearn just to show that the results match.</span>
<span class="c1"># Import sklearn</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">sklearn.linear_model</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">LinearRegression</span>
<span class="c1"># Intitialize a model; we want an intercept term included</span>
<span class="n">sk_linreg</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">LinearRegression</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">fit_intercept</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">False</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="c1"># Fit the model</span>
<span class="n">sk_linreg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fit</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="c1"># Print the results</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">sk_linreg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">coef_</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>[[ 1.11764069e+01 -3.24615547e-05]]
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>And now let's load up <code>statsmodels</code>:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [11]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Now time for statsmodels!</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">statsmodels.api</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">sm</span>

<span class="c1"># Train the model using our training data</span>
<span class="n">lin_mod1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">sm</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">OLS</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="c1"># Fitting the models</span>
<span class="n">lm1_results</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">lin_mod1</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fit</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="c1"># Check our stats!</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">lm1_results</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">params</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># Creating predictions for plotting/scoring purposes</span>
<span class="n">y_pred_train_lm1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">lm1_results</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">predict</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">y_pred_test_lm1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">lm1_results</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">predict</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_test</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>[ 1.11764069e+01 -3.24615547e-05]
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>You can see that the general procedures are nearly identical!  The only additional steps we perform are creating some predictions for plotting and performance analysis. We conclude by printing out the coefficients and as you can see, they two methods agree in the results. But consider how you assess the model in sklearn.</p>
<p>Normally we would run cross validation and pick some metrics to evaluate on. But really, all we can do is compare certain models to others (or baselines) and maybe assess some plots. This is far from the most scientific evaluation process. This is where <code>statsmodels</code> differentiates itself from <code>sklearn</code>. Instead of just putting out coefficients or scoring on some metrics, we now have a large number of statistical tests:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [12]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># But unlike sklearn, this returns a whole suite of statistical results! </span>
<span class="c1"># Let's check them out:</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">lm1_results</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">summary</span><span class="p">())</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>                            OLS Regression Results                            
==============================================================================
Dep. Variable:                   Temp   R-squared:                       0.000
Model:                            OLS   Adj. R-squared:                 -0.000
Method:                 Least Squares   F-statistic:                    0.1859
Date:                Mon, 25 Apr 2022   Prob (F-statistic):              0.666
Time:                        20:22:31   Log-Likelihood:                -9288.8
No. Observations:                3285   AIC:                         1.858e+04
Df Residuals:                    3283   BIC:                         1.859e+04
Df Model:                           1                                         
Covariance Type:            nonrobust                                         
==============================================================================
                 coef    std err          t      P>|t|      [0.025      0.975]
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Intercept     11.1764      0.143     78.290      0.000      10.897      11.456
Time       -3.246e-05   7.53e-05     -0.431      0.666      -0.000       0.000
==============================================================================
Omnibus:                       17.601   Durbin-Watson:                   0.451
Prob(Omnibus):                  0.000   Jarque-Bera (JB):               17.825
Skew:                           0.180   Prob(JB):                     0.000135
Kurtosis:                       2.981   Cond. No.                     3.79e+03
==============================================================================

Notes:
[1] Standard Errors assume that the covariance matrix of the errors is correctly specified.
[2] The condition number is large, 3.79e+03. This might indicate that there are
strong multicollinearity or other numerical problems.
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This provides a great amount of useful statistical information to the DS/ML practitioner. The downside is that there is a large amount of information and parsing it out can be difficult and require a more detailed background in statistics. I'll put a summary of the metrics below (with links) that you can follow later if you want.</p>
<h3 id="Fields/Metrics-you-should-always-look-at:">Fields/Metrics you should always look at:<a class="anchor-link" href="#Fields/Metrics-you-should-always-look-at:">¶</a></h3><ol>
<li><code>Dep. Variable</code> - Always good to make sure you are predicting what you think you are predicting.</li>
<li><code>R-squared/Adj. R-Squared</code> - This shows the proportion of variance in $\vec{y}$ that is explained by the independent variables $\mathbb{X}$ with 0 being the answer you would get if you predict the $\bar{y}$. It is bounded above by 1 (perfect explanation) and can go to $-\infty$ (terrible). See following <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coefficient_of_determination#Adjusted_R2">Wikipedia link</a> for more details about $R^{2}$ and $Adj. R^{2}$</li>
<li><code>Prob (F-Statistic)</code> - Most classical Linear Regression models will compute an ANOVA on the model to test the hypothesis that all coefficients are 0 (outside of the <code>intercept</code>). I'd highly recommend section 6.2 of <a href="http://barbra-coco.dyndns.org/yuri/plan_answers_to_complex_question.pdf">Plane Answers to Complex Problems</a> for a wonderful treatment of this.</li>
<li>The <code>t</code> and <code>P>|t|</code> regression values -  Since each of the coefficients follows a $t$-distribution under the model hypothesis, we can use these tests to see which coefficients appear to belong in the model. So knowing the t-values and associated probablities can be very helpful in determining feature selection. Sections 2.7 & 6.2 of <a href="http://barbra-coco.dyndns.org/yuri/plan_answers_to_complex_question.pdf">Plane Answers to Complex Problems</a> have great details on this.</li>
<li><code>Prob(Omnibus)</code> and <code>Prob(JB)</code> - These metrics relate to <code>Omnibus</code> and <code>Jarque-Bera (JB)</code> tests respectively. Both are tied to the notion of <code>Skew</code> and <code>Kurtosis</code> and relate to assessing the Gausian assumption of the model. The <code>Omnibus</code> metric is actually <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D%27Agostino%27s_K-squared_test">D'Agostino's K-squared-test</a> and you can read the associated link as well as this link for more details on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jarque%E2%80%93Bera_test">Jarque-Bera</a>.</li>
</ol>
<h3 id="Additional-Metrics">Additional Metrics<a class="anchor-link" href="#Additional-Metrics">¶</a></h3><ol>
<li><code>AIC/BIC</code>$^{\star}$ - These are two functions based on the log-likelihood of the model that penalize you for the number of paramters you have (BIC the most strongly). These only make sense when you are running multiple models though as a means for comparing performance. We usually do make multiple runs though, so just good to keep in the back of your mind. More details on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akaike_information_criterion">AIC</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_information_criterion">BIC</a> are available here.</li>
<li><code>Durbin-Watson</code> - The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Durbin%E2%80%93Watson_statistic">Durbin-Watson test</a> checks the assumption of independent observations (rather than corrrelation). The reason this isn't a "Must See" is because you would have to manually find the critical values. An "okay" rule of thumb is that any values between 1.5 and 2.5 are okay.</li>
<li><code>Cond. No.</code> - This is matrix technique to see if there is any multi-collinearity in the data. This can be misleading though depending on the scale of the data. Section 15.1 of <a href="http://barbra-coco.dyndns.org/yuri/plan_answers_to_complex_question.pdf">Plane Answers to Complex Problems</a> defines this more clearly.</li>
<li><code>Skew</code> and <code>Kurtosis</code> - It's a good idea to look at these as well, as it may help you see a significant problem highlighed by <code>Prob(Omnibus)</code> and <code>Prob(JB)</code>.  </li>
</ol>
<p>But let's move on to see some plots!</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [13]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Let's visualize the data</span>
<span class="n">fig</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">ax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">subplots</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">figsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">20</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">6</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">train_df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Date'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">test_df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Date'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">color</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'r'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">train_df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Date'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">y_pred_train_lm1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'k-'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">label</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'Simple lm'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">linewidth</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">test_df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Date'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">y_pred_test_lm1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'k:'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">label</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'Simple lm - Pred'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">linewidth</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_title</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Daily Min Temps in Melbourne'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">fontsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">20</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">yaxis</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_label_text</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Temp'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">xaxis</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_label_text</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Date'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">legend</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">loc</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'upper left'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">fontsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">14</span><span class="p">);</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Normaly we plot the data quickly when possible to help gain intuition, but in this case I thought it would be good to see the statistics <em>first</em> before looking at the plot. I did this to show that the statistical outputs are helpful in assessing the fit.  We note that the fit is poor ($R^{2}$ = 0, $P(F-Stat) = 0.66$, etc...). The "traditional" approach that is used to add some periodicity to the data is to add an indicator function for each month (and dropping the intercept term). Unfortunately the fits are far from realistic, appearing like some kind of periodic staircase. To improve this you could have indicator functions for weeks or even specific days, which will make the plots smoother, but at the cost of injecting a great deal of variance into the model, with each point having very few training points. Fortunately, we can do quite a bit more if we want, but it will involve some extra concepts AND shattering a major myth about Linear Regression.</p>
<p>Nearly every course on ML begins by covering traditional Linear Regression. Yet in nearly most cases (particularly in courses that do not emphasize Statistical ML), the technique is marginalized by instructors who say things like "We are looking at this to build intuition, but nobody really uses this any more because all it can do is make lines/hyperplanes", or words to that effect. At first glance, this reasoning may seem reasonable (it is called "Linear" Regression after all), but it turns out this is <strong>completely false</strong>!</p>
<p>More formally, a Linear Regression model assumes that (given a label, feature vector pair: $(y, \vec{\pmb{x}})$) that $$y = \vec{\pmb{\theta}}^{\top}\vec{\pmb{x}} + \epsilon,~~\mathbb{E}[\epsilon|\vec{\pmb{x}}] = \mathbb{E}[\epsilon] = 0.$$ Note that $\vec{\pmb{x}}$ does not have any non-unitary exponents and therefore the resulting dot product is a simple linear sum of vector elements: $$\vec{\pmb{\theta}}^{\top}\vec{\pmb{x}} = \sum_{i = 1}^{k}w_{i}\cdot x_{i}.$$ But consider a hypothetical example where $\vec{\pmb{x}} = [1~~x_{1}]^{\top}$ and $\vec{\pmb{\theta}} = [\theta_{0}~~\theta_{1}]^{\top}$. If we created a new variable, $x_{2} := x_{1}^{2}$ and defined $\vec{\pmb{x}'} := [1~~x_{1}~~x_{2}]^{\top}$ and $\vec{\pmb{\theta}'} := [\theta_{0}~~\theta_{1}~~\theta_{2}]^{\top}$, would it be valid to try and model $y = \vec{\pmb{\theta}'}^{\top}\vec{\pmb{x}'}$? Of course it would! From an equation point-of-view, there the two equations are identical in the abstract sense, even though one of the columns is a nonlinear function of another. If you are still unconvinced, try and estimate this in your own programming language of choice to confirm this if you want; the machinery has no idea that one column is a square of the other.</p>
<p>So why is it called "Linear" regression, when we clearly can have columns that are non-linear functions of other columns? This is because Linear Regression is not required to be linear in $\vec{\pmb{x}}$; instead it <em>must be linear in</em> $\vec{\pmb{\theta}}$! Put in other words, we can solve $$y = \vec{\pmb{\theta}}^{\top}\phi\left(\vec{\pmb{x}}\right) + \epsilon$$ where $$\phi:\mathbb{R}^{k}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{l}$$ where (typically in practice) $k < l$.  To make this more concrete, we can have valid regression models when we use <a href="https://www.cs.princeton.edu/courses/archive/fall18/cos324/files/basis-functions.pdf">Basis Functions</a> (the $\phi(\cdot)$ functions referenced earlier). Now in this case, I'm going to skip using a Fourier basis function which would likely be a great decision given this (clearly periodic) data, and instead utilize a Gaussian Radial Basis Function. To do this, we need to do a bit of grunt work first.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [15]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Let's put some radial basis functions in for fun</span>
<span class="c1"># We'll make a new version of the training and test feature data</span>
<span class="n">train_df1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">train_df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">copy</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">test_df1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">test_df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">copy</span><span class="p">()</span>

<span class="c1"># We'll create a function to find an rbf. The function takes in some "centerpoint" known as `datestart`</span>
<span class="c1"># and then converts that centered point into the current year of the record in the data. It then finds</span>
<span class="c1"># the delta between the date in question and the current date of the record, accounts for deltas in years </span>
<span class="c1"># and returns the function valuated at that point with our given `gamma` parameter</span>
<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">rbf_date</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">datestart</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">gamma</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">date</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">to_datetime</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">datestart</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">mo</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">date</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">month</span>
    <span class="n">dy</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">date</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">day</span>
    <span class="n">raw_delta</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Date'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Timestamp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">year</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Year'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">month</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">mo</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">day</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">dy</span><span class="p">))</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">days</span>
    <span class="n">delta</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">min</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">abs</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">raw_delta</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">abs</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">raw_delta</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mi">365</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">abs</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">raw_delta</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="mi">365</span><span class="p">))</span>
    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">exp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">gamma</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">delta</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">**</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [16]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Let's make one basis function per month:</span>
<span class="n">num_rbfs</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">12</span>

<span class="c1"># We now want to make the actual centerpoints for the functions. This code will use list comprehension</span>
<span class="c1"># to make a spike centered on the 1st of every month of 2020.</span>
<span class="c1"># NOTE: you can put the spikes on any date you want.</span>
<span class="n">rbf_dates</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">to_datetime</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">i</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="s1">'/1/2020'</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">i</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">range</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_rbfs</span><span class="p">)]</span> 

<span class="c1"># And now let's look at the results.</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">rbf_dates</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>[Timestamp('2020-01-01 00:00:00'), Timestamp('2020-02-01 00:00:00'), Timestamp('2020-03-01 00:00:00'), Timestamp('2020-04-01 00:00:00'), Timestamp('2020-05-01 00:00:00'), Timestamp('2020-06-01 00:00:00'), Timestamp('2020-07-01 00:00:00'), Timestamp('2020-08-01 00:00:00'), Timestamp('2020-09-01 00:00:00'), Timestamp('2020-10-01 00:00:00'), Timestamp('2020-11-01 00:00:00'), Timestamp('2020-12-01 00:00:00')]
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [17]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># We need a gamma value...</span>
<span class="n">our_gamma</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">750</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># And now time to make the basis functions!</span>
<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">i</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">range</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_rbfs</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">train_df1</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'rbf_'</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">)]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">train_df1</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">rbf_date</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">datestart</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">rbf_dates</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">gamma</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">our_gamma</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">axis</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">test_df1</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'rbf_'</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">)]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">test_df1</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">rbf_date</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">datestart</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">rbf_dates</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">gamma</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">our_gamma</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">axis</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [19]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># What does this look like for a year?</span>
<span class="n">train_df1</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">train_df1</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Year'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="mi">1988</span><span class="p">][[</span><span class="s1">'rbf_'</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">i</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">range</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_rbfs</span><span class="p">)]]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">figsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">20</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">));</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [20]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># What does this look like for all the data?</span>
<span class="n">train_df1</span><span class="p">[[</span><span class="s1">'rbf_'</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">i</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">range</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_rbfs</span><span class="p">)]]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">figsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">20</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">));</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now we'll use <code>patsy</code> again! In this case, we have a number of other features we'd like to include to the regressor. Rather than selecting the columns with .loc/.iloc or having to manually create the formula, we can instead append the names to a string.</p>
<p>Remember as well that these formulas can become quite complex (i.e. if we included an interaction term, etc...) so it still beneficial to remain in the Patsy paradigm.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [21]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Naming the formula for the linear regression</span>
<span class="n">formula2</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">"Temp ~ 0 + Time"</span>
<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">i</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">range</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_rbfs</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">formula2</span> <span class="o">+=</span> <span class="s1">' + rbf_'</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">formula2</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Temp ~ 0 + Time + rbf_0 + rbf_1 + rbf_2 + rbf_3 + rbf_4 + rbf_5 + rbf_6 + rbf_7 + rbf_8 + rbf_9 + rbf_10 + rbf_11
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [22]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Use Patsy to make the required matrices/arrays</span>
<span class="n">y_train1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">X_train1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">dmatrices</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">formula2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">data</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">train_df1</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">y_test1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">X_test1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">dmatrices</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">formula2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">data</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">test_df1</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>So now that we have the new features (RBF features) and our new design matrices, let's fit the model and see how we do!</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [23]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Train the model using our training data</span>
<span class="n">lin_mod2</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">sm</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">OLS</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_train1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">X_train1</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="c1"># Fitting the models</span>
<span class="n">lm2_results</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">lin_mod2</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fit</span><span class="p">()</span>

<span class="c1"># Make predictions</span>
<span class="n">y_pred_train_lm2</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">lm2_results</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">predict</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_train1</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">y_pred_test_lm2</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">lm2_results</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">predict</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_test1</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="c1"># Check our stats!</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">lm2_results</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">summary</span><span class="p">())</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>                                 OLS Regression Results                                
=======================================================================================
Dep. Variable:                   Temp   R-squared (uncentered):                   0.946
Model:                            OLS   Adj. R-squared (uncentered):              0.946
Method:                 Least Squares   F-statistic:                              4397.
Date:                Tue, 26 Apr 2022   Prob (F-statistic):                        0.00

                 coef    std err          t      P>|t|      [0.025      0.975]
